facts.text: Appellant filed suit for partition and recovery of possession of his half share in certain properties.
Dispute referred to arbitration on joint petition on January 22, 1948. B Form Diary entry: 'Subject matter of suit is referred to Arbitration on joint petition. Call on 24-2-1948.'
On February 24, 1948, case adjourned to March 25, 1948, with remark 'call on'.
On March 25, 1948, diary entry: 'Further time wanted. File Award 23-6-1948.'
On June 28, 1948, 'Call on 6-7-1948.' Award was actually ready on June 28, 1948.
Award filed in court on July 6, 1948. Objections on 13-7-1948.
Appellant made application on July 2, 1948, for superseding the arbitration.
Area of land allotted to appellant is less than half the total area of the land in suit, but no indication that value is less than half.
Madras High Court judgment and order dated April 6, 1953, in Appeal against order No. 54 of 1949.

legal_issues.text: Whether the reference to arbitration was invalid because the Court failed to comply with the mandatory requirements of s. 23, sub-s. (1) of the Arbitration Act, 1940, by not specifying the time within which the award was to be made in the order of reference.
Whether the award was invalid because it was filed in Court by the arbitrator after the expiry of the time subsequently granted by the Court for filing the award.
Whether the arbitrator erred in allotting to the appellant less than half the share in the properties in suit.

petitioner_arguments.text: Reference to arbitration invalid as Court omitted to specify time for award in the order of reference itself, violating mandatory s. 23(1) Arbitration Act.
Award filed on July 6, 1948, after expiry of time fixed till June 23, 1948.
Application made on July 2, 1948, to supersede arbitration before award filed, so award could not be filed thereafter.
Arbitrator allotted less than half share in properties (less area), making award bad on its face and otherwise invalid under s. 30(c).

court_reasoning.text: Fixation of time for award is imperative, but not necessary to specify in order of reference itself if fixed elsewhere in proceedings. Diary entry 'Call on 24-2-1948' implies time fixed by February 24, 1948. Reading diary with order, reference valid.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Emphasis on fixation of time in some manner, not expressly in order of reference.

court_reasoning.text: Time extended multiple times: Feb 24 to Mar 25; Mar 25 to Jun 23; Jun 23 to Jun 28; Jun 28 to Jul 6. Award ready Jun 28, filed Jul 6 within extensions.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Diary entries show repeated extensions by Court.

court_reasoning.text: Application to supersede on Jul 2 ineffective as award already made before that date; mere application does not affect reference.

Area less but value not shown to be less than half. No material to say appellant received less than due share. Award not set aside under s.30 unless misconduct, supersession, or improperly procured/otherwise invalid. Not bad on face; arbitrator decided honestly.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No suggestion of dishonesty; objection does not fall under s.30 grounds.

holdings.text: Reference to arbitration valid despite time not specified in order itself, as fixed in diary proceedings.
Award filed within extended time; supersession application belated and ineffective.
No error in allotment; award not invalid under s.30 as no misconduct or invalidity shown.

precedents_cited.case_name: Raja Har Narain Singh v. Chaudhain Bhagawant Kuar and another
precedents_cited.relevance: Provisions of s.508 CPC 1882 correspond to s.23 Arbitration Act; fixation of time in some manner sufficient, even if not in order of reference; subsequent extensions valid.

statutes_cited.name: Arbitration Act, 1940
statutes_cited.relevance: s.23(1) requires time fixation for award (imperative but manner flexible); s.30 limits grounds for setting aside award (misconduct, supersession, improper procurement/otherwise invalid)

outcome.summary: Appeal by special leave dismissed as there is no substance in any of the three grounds challenging the validity of the arbitrator's award.

key_quotes.text: What is imperative is the fixation of the time for making the award. But it does not follow that where the Court omits to specify the time in the order of reference but does so elsewhere in the proceedings, the reference is bad.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: In our opinion there is no substance in any of these grounds.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: under s. 30 of the Act an award can be set aside only on the following three grounds...
key_quotes.speaker: court
